summary: The case concerns three French nationals, Guido Annoni di Gussola, Valérie Desbordes, and Stéphane Omer, who lodged applications with the European Commission of Human Rights (the Commission) under Article 25 of the Convention for the Protection of Human Rights and Fundamental Freedoms (the Convention). The applicants complained that they were denied access to the Court of Cassation to appeal on points of law against adverse judgments of the courts of appeal, despite their limited financial means. The applicants relied on Article 6 § 1 of the Convention, which guarantees the right to a fair trial. The French Government argued that the applicants' appeals were inadmissible due to the removal of their appeals from the Court of Cassation list. The Commission decided to communicate the applications to the Government and invited them to make written observations on their admissibility and merits. The Court declared the applications admissible and held a public hearing. The judges considered that the facts and circumstances of the case had a consequence on the way norms and standards of the Convention were applied, as the applicants' denial of access to the Court of Cassation violated their right to a fair trial under Article 6 § 1 of the Convention.
